Ross, serious Roman Catholic that he is, gemli, is eager to display his articulate prowess and mastery of words that, in Shakespeare's "MacBeth" assessment, amount to strutting and fretting upon the stage. But meaning? Nothing.

Meanwhile the result of his party's political game-man-ship is that the nation is further behind as a society and culture than it's peers and will be, if they have their way, completely back to The Gilded Age over the next 2 - 4 years.

For moral Ross what matters is making sure that the reader be educated in the fine art of P.C.; don't look at what we're doing, see how much more word clever we are.

Miranda, why do you say "even the most advanced" hospitals. If anything, it is precisely the most advanced (and expensive) hospitals that are looking at ways to improve the patient experience (at least in Mass.).

one final comment. It seems that the plea deal negotiated by the prosecutor was not approved. My guess is that there was a presentencing report and there was something in it. Most likely related to the young man's behavior in the juvenile home, where he was observed in action.

We do not know what he did the last time he got in trouble out with his buddies, what he did in juvenile detention, and based on that information what may be likely the next time he is out with his buddies. It is too bad, but there is a problem here and it was not created by the prosecutors..
... especially, after spending some time at a juvenile facility prior to this incident.

Mr. Luettegen,
One of the most powerful images that I retain of the President is the one where he is standing with lowered head and shielding his eyes when told of the massacre of the children of Syria. He spoke to us about the importance of intervening during a summer past, and we all started to grouse and go home.

He placed a call to us when people took refuge on a mountain in the Middle East not so long ago, and it is the picture of an Arab woman holding her dead child in her arms, invoking the President's name for help, that is the most evocative to this American, but our ears for the most part remained leaden, and our eyes were dull and glazed over.

Today he is going along the road of America and taking up the banner for the very poor, while encouraging us to better educate our children. At times Mr. Obama will tell us that he 'hears' us, but do we hear him when there is a call on his part for any good action?

The choice is ours, and when it comes to true empathy and action, it is to President Obama that I turn, and to my friends who late in life have become my true family. 'Is Christianity dead', asked an elderly Iraqi recently when I visited and taking this person by surprise? And, tough that friend has had to be at times in their life to bring their family here over the decades to safety. Perhaps it is a bit of our Humanity that is being slowly taken away from us, was my reply, but we are not going to give up ever. Always.

Friends on mission often return from Darfur via Abu Dhabi for a visit home rather than Khartoum. One of them, an Operations Officer on site, rarely if ever buys anything for herself, told me of a plain gold bangle that caught her eye in transit, and we both had a good laugh when she found out that it cost $32,000.

In the meantime, more and more Africans are going to Egypt as slave-laborers for work, and the conditions under which they live often without their family, is another tragedy that is now being addressed, although some of these workers will never be able to return home again. Lost and forgotten in the sand dunes, while the world continues to spin.

I doubt very much that there would be public support for sending troops to Sudan at this point. The public is tired after years of inconclusive war and is in any case reluctant to commit American troops in large numbers when our national interests aren't at stake and, increasingly, even when they are. Besides, how effective would the be? Look at what happened in Iraq, look at what happened in Afghanistan.

The problem, of course, is that many if not most of the worst offenders already are sanctioned by the West -- additional sanctions that don't actually starve the peoples involved probably won't have immense impact. The only way to affect genocidal reality is to block the securing of objectives that the genocide is meant to support. Most of those objectives have to do with eliminating what elites regard as alien presences among them, competing for land, other material resources and a say in development of a shared culture. And most of them are racial or ethnic by nature.

If sanctions likely won't be effective, then the only remaining way of stopping genocide is by force. Certainly, moral suasion alone is the first and last resort of the monumentally naive.

For most of the past seventy years, it has fallen to the U.S. to apply that force, because Europe has increasingly eviscerated its armed forces in the interests of paying for its social welfare frameworks -- it's simply no longer capable of militarily and independently defending its interests. The last time WE did it effectively, though it took time and actually did pull in some European help, was in the Balkans.

But Mr. Obama clearly does not embrace this view of America's role, whatever his motivations. He is fast becoming today's archetypal "bystander".

I support Nick's passion and outrage. But merely talking about the outrage doesn't get troops flown to Sudan and South Sudan.

As another physician, I'd say this is a good time to question the motivation of the American Academy of Pediatrics. Are they afraid there will be negative economic consequences if they take a strong stand on this? Their position gives a good example that re-inforces your point that the public's  mistrust of the medical establishment has basis in reality.
Anyone else troubled by the actions of the bus driver? Surprised he gets a pass on this.
So many of us in this country agree with you - it really is time to overcome whatever it is that prevents us from organizing effectively and making it happen.

In my state, California, there have been some articles in the papers recently about the possibility of an Assisted Suicide Law. Without knowing all of the details I am assuming it would be something similar to the Assisted Suicide laws in the other states thatalready have it.

I am all in favor of this and would vigorously support it. I am a stage 3 colon cancer survivor and if at some point in the future I am diagnosed with a terminal disease and my final days would be extremely unpleasant and a tremendous burden to my loved ones I would want to have the option of assisted suicide to painlessly and peacefully end my life on my terms.

California has a reputation for being a very progressive state and I would hope that this spirit would enable the passage of an assisted suicide law. I would also hope that the various religious representatives would abandon their misguided attempt to stop it's passage. As long as reasonable safeguards are made part of the law so it is not abused by greedy relatives seeking to speed up their inheritance the bottom line in my case is that it is my life and my decision if I want to end it.

Finally I want to say that I considered Jack Kervorkian to be a true hero because he sacrificed so much in order to advance the acceptance of assisted suicide.

There is a difference between refusing to have your child vaccinated and having a child who is medically unable to take the vaccine.  Appointments would have to be scheduled at a time when there were not young infants in the office but if I were a pediatrician I would do my best to work with the families of children who cannot take the vaccine.
As long as our system is "fee for service," physicians will continue aggressive but pointless treatment and blame it on "the family."

Some yes, but not all.  I have known both, and I think that the belief that all physicians only do it for the money does a disservice to those practitioners who don't; those practitioners who truly try to do what is best for the patient.  In fact, that was one of the criteria I used for choosing which Oncologist I went to when I was diagnosed with breast cancer.  I chose an Oncologist who avoided "aggressive but pointless treatments", and I try to do the same for my patients.

I am a physician, and have taken care of many who were approaching or at the end of their lives.  I agree that the approach to death and dying in this country needs to change.  There have been some comments made about physicians who pursue aggressive treatments regardless of prognosis or quality of life.  While I don't disagree that there are those type of physicians out there (and there are many), as a physician who values quality of life over quantity of life, and who tries to practice accordingly, I would also say that many families (not all) need to change how they approach the care of their loved one.  I have often heard family members insist that their loved one is "a fighter", as if this is some sort of war to be won, or who see choosing palliative care as "giving up".  I have been told that "Hospice kills people".  I also think that some family members choose aggressive measures because they never discussed end-of life wishes with their loved one, and feel unsure about what their loved one would want (and, by default, go with "do everything").  Sadly, many of these patients die miserable deaths.  Almost everyone I have met would want to die a "good death": peaceful, enjoying what little time they have left, surrounded by friends and family.  I would encourage all who have not done so to make their wishes known (re: CPR, intubation, feeding tubes, and even dialysis) and choose your medical power of attorney wisely.

The anti-scientific nonsense Americans buy into is amazing.  It seems that the vaccine-deniers are only creating disease risk for themselves and others like them.  If they paid for their own healthcare, why not just let them be jerks?  But if they are guaranteed access to health insurance, then they ask everyone else to cover their completely avoidable higher risks.  They have the right to buy into nonsense, but not on my dime.  I even think one could charge parents who deny their children immunizations with child abuse, since it is mostly children who come down with the illnesses that their parents sensibly already have been immunized against.

My grandfather, father, mother-in-law, uncle, brother-in-law, brother, and nephew all died from cancer. My mother died from Parkinson's disease after spending the last years of her life in our home. My last remaining brother now has cancer. I have watched as they died, some in agony and some peacefully, some over many months and some quickly. I have been unburdened of any belief that medicine saves lives. At most it alters the mode of death or defers it. In the end all of us must deal with the consequences of our mortality and the often-painful machinations of disease.

What medicine can do, and should become even better at doing, is relieve the symptoms of disease and injury. Those of my family who were prepared for death by experienced and caring hospice nurses retained more of their abilities and endured less discomfort than most of those who did not. The drugs and medical devices that eased their failing bodies and reasserted their dignity were made available before they were needed, and the family was coached in their use.

"Do not go gentle into that good night" may seem romantic and heroic, but in the end having the option of a more gentle departure from this life is for most the much better choice. I appreciate the doctors for their tenacious efforts to stave off death, but I hold the hospice nurses who have helped my family on too many occasions deep in my heart.

When I was a child in the mid 1950's we had a neighbor kid with one leg shorter than the other due to having had polio. Apparently he missed the Saulk vaccine by only a year or two.  We made fun of him (something of which I am ashamed to this day).  Parents who blithely refuse to vaccinate grew up surrounded by vaccinated classmates and have never experienced the horror of some of the world's most deadly scourges.  Sadly I have friends here in,,,you guessed it, Orange County, California who perfectly fit the description offered in the editorial: they distrust doctors, pharma and live a healthy life style, or so they think, if smoking dope is part of that regime. When I gently challenge them they cannot cite any specific study, certainly nothing done with the rigor or science. But then, these are the same parents who think you can affirm your way to prosperity and cure yourself of cancer with laughter. All that New Age stuff is helpful and powerful, but when the Universe offers your children protection in the form of rigorous medical science, there comes a time for Acceptance.

The only problem with your statement is that they are intellectual and educated. Most of these folks have only a rudimentary science background. Studying humanities in college is great but it does not make one any more capable of interpreting science than someone with little or no education (perhaps it makes it worse).

Ms. Dowd seems to be pining for the real Mitt Romney but who's to say who the real Mitt Romney really is?  In actuality, the real Mitt Romney is a guy named Willard Mitt Romney who apparently can't even bear to acknowledge his given name. Apart from that, he's spent his career in politics freely moving between the pros and cons of every position under the sun. Is he in favor of women's reproductive rights? Universal health care? Addressing income inequality? Depends on what day of the week it is. When he spoke of the 47% of Americans who are "takers" he did so without realizing he was being recorded. Generally speaking, people are at their most candid when they believe they're speaking privately.  Then again, perhaps he was simply telling his audience of major contributors what he thought they wanted to hear.  Who's to say...really?  To get to know the real "Mitt" Romney we'd probably have to introduce him to alcohol.  Or coffee.  Or sodium pentothal.

The CDC makes the same argument that you do here, that "what seems to be a large number of infectious agents introduced via vaccines is tiny compared to the number a child is exposed to in the environment on a normal day."

But this argument seems to me dishonest coming from anyone who is familiar with the vaccination process. Any doctor will tell you, post vaccine, that your child will likely experience a rash, maybe some vomiting, crankiness, sleeplessness, as their immune system responds to the injected antigens. This is good, it means the vaccine is working. It also means, to me, that injection of antigens is different from normal daily exposures. Most children do not experience rashes, sleeplessness, long bouts of crying everyday, but only after a vaccine.

I am not saying that vaccination is a bad decision. I am saying that the CDC logic that multiple simultaneous vaccines is the same as multiple daily exposure to bacteria, etc. is very dishonest. It is effectively a lie. It also calls into question their assurance that multiple vaccines are certainly no more dangerous than single vaccines. There is currently no evidence otherwise - this is all they really have. If the CDC is so sure of these things, then communicate the evidence to the public - don't give me nonsense that vaccines are the same as oral exposure to dirt and bacteria.

gratianus:

I didn't claim ownership of the "conservative" view: I merely documented it. My own view is considerably less stark in its survivalist and Libertarian emphasis. However, where does the rationale to remove free will from the individual in the interests of an elite's perception of the needs of the common good end? In any case, Frank's notion of forced vaccination is absurd in America, and we would be better served by an intelligent program of public education, and less bootless resort to talk of forcing people to do anything. These kinds of musings are largely responsible for an entirely Republican-majority Congress, as many Americans listen to what liberal collectivists regard as sensible, and ... simply run.

As to your mangling, I advise either a better quality of scotch before commenting; or, as in my case, putting off its enjoyment until AFTER I've submitted my nightly offerings.

It is undeniable that the vaccine industry is a cash cow --there is no other business I can think of where the government literally guarantees you millions of new customers each year. For that reason, parents are wise to ask a lot of questions. I'm glad we don't have mercury in many of the childhood vaccines anymore --and you can thank the crazy anti-vaxxers for that.
When my child was born (1997), I had a brilliant, wonderful pediatrician, who teaches at a major university hospital here in Chicago. One of his classes educates medical students on the realities of the pharmaceutical industry and how to stay objective as a doctor.
He told me there was no question that vaccines save lives, but that he had also seen some children have terrible reactions to them. He said we should be doing research to figure out which children were vulnerable and why, in order to develop alternatives for them. But that it would never happen because the medical and pharmaceutical industries (and the influential publications they advertise in...) deny or minimize adverse reactions.

He believed in most vaccines, but not all of them. He advised against the rotavirus and later the HPV vaccines. And he believed the standard vaccination schedule was too aggressive time-wise. Since I was doing extended nursing and my child wasn't in day care, he recommended a much slower vaccination schedule. It was wonderful to work with a doctor who respected my concerns.

Children are exposed to more antigens (molecules which cause an immune reaction; eg: proteins from bacteria and viruses in the environment or in a shot) on a daily basis just in the environment than what they get when vaccinated on the existing schedule. Though concerns of 'overwhelming the immune system' might cross parents' minds, they are unfounded and do not square with our knowledge of the human immune system, which is capable of handling lots of 'threats' at a time.

The CDC has some more information on this subject: http://www.cdc.gov/vaccinesafety/Vaccines/multiplevaccines.html
FYI. We know as much about our immune system as we know about our brain. That is, not much at all. And that includes the people who work at the CDC!

I think Eula Biss's book, "On Immunity" should be required reading. She points out that the smallpox vaccine that people of my generation received in the 50's carried a larger load than all 14 of the vaccines children received today.

I made sure my children were vaccinated, and my grandchildren have been vaccinated. What I am uncomfortable with today is the number of vaccines given in a single office visit to fit them all in as young as possible. That is purely a cost-saving time-management measure or pediatricians would be more amenable to parents' concerns about overwhelming the immune system.

Why can't vaccinations be given a month apart as a precaution, if parents request, instead of multiples given during checkups spaced at 4, 6, or 12 month intervals? They would not even have to involve the doctor if a nurse or PA was available.

Vaccinations are important for children and our population at large, as we see with the new outbreaks of measles and whooping cough, but I have real concerns about the rigidity of the vaccine schedule currently imposed, and the unforeseen consequences it may have for some children. If pediatricians would work with parents, they might find some are not so against immunizations as they are against the schedule.
These are photos of life, not death.

To "work with" those parents is to enable them in their dangerous behavior. Keeping those parents and child in your care condones a very important destructive behavior in the parents.

If a physician sees evidence of physical abuse of a child, she is required by law to report such abuse for a good reason. And after having seen such evidence and reported it, "working with" the family means taking actions in concert with the government to help/force these parents to change.

Unfortunately, non-vaccination is not yet categorized legally as child abuse. As a physician, and not an attorney, I see no difference.
